text: Afternoon everyone Thanks for joining us for this chat or for not leaving after that excellent chat we just had We are here today you might have seen the agenda it's so much like a vendor pitch it more comes out of the customer success story area of KCD Talks I'll let you decide how successful it is at the end of the chat Who are we chatting about My name is Duncan Wright I'm a senior platform engineer working at Bayley Gifford I'm joined by Andrew Garner who's also on the platform's team Our other colleague Chris contributed to these slides but couldn't be here today so we left him in there just for getting the credit as well Bayley Gifford itself we're an investment management firm so like a lot of the businesses in Edinburgh highly regulated work in finance I'm sure people in the room will know what that's like We were founded and headquartered and have remained in Edinburgh since 1908 That's a slightly misleading sentence like we left but we've been here for 117 years well known local business so we're a good pick for representing KCD in Edinburgh today Across the firm there's about 1 600 people about 500 of those across the dev and infrastructure teams and they are serviced by a platform team of about 12 people so that's just to give you the scale of what kind of company size we are Today we'll chat about where we were pre migration pre this new modern Kubernetes setup that we'll talk to you about today how we built that platform decisions we made a lot of them of course are Kubernetes related but it's also touching on Terraform and other platform decisions we made The great migration once we built it we have to get people to actually use it and the various problems that that comes with I'll look at where we are now and then I'll look at the future to see what kind of things are coming The idea of this chat is hopefully it will spark some ideas within you or discussions or something along those lines that you might try and implement yourselves Before the past we had a number of on premises self hosted clusters or semi self hosted We used PKS the pivotal container service from VMware largely due to just an existing vendor relationship more than anything else This came with a number of challenges It was a kind of non standard implementation of Kubernetes Upgrades could be difficult a lot of support calls and whatnot so this is where we were With all these points they're kind of points of friction that came from decisions that were good at the time but aged less well perhaps We provisioned those clusters and configured all the tooling on them with imperative scripts We've heard a lot of chats today about declarative v imperative The overriding idea at the time was that there was no problem that Bash couldn't solve and that's what drove this kind of thing But these were largely fire and forget They weren't great for error handling and all those things that I'm sure you'll have come across We ran those scripts using Azure DevOps pipelines We're largely a Microsoft house We use a lot of Azure tools Azure DevOps pipelines have their place like GitHub Actions They're good for CICD but not necessarily for something that's less frequent like these cluster creation and upgrade processes And through all this we had no concept of state So once you ran these scripts you create your clusters how did you know what was actually there and live and in production People could change things in production and then we would have no idea until you ran the script again and saw some sort of problem So that's where we were Absolutely fine like I say decisions were made that were well intentioned at the time but over time they caused friction That's kind of where we are And so we thought what kind of targeted improvements could we see What could we get from migrating both to the cloud and changing the ways that we structure our clusters And the number one saving number one improvement sorry was cost saving So at the time we were looking at buying a new hardware on prem and whether it was worth the capital expenditure versus operational We looked at moving to the cloud and thought there was a huge chance for cost saving there Obviously one of the things is you only pay for what you use So that's an obvious kind of benefit We were moved to then a single managed platform We had PKS on prem We also then dabbled with Azure Kubernetes Service AKS We were then writing the scripts to work for two different environments It was getting messy Going into one single platform of course simplifies everything And the fact that it's managed for you is a huge bonus So again easy for us people on call et cetera Working in Azure working in the cloud allowed us to be more cloud native with our development processes as in we were closer to all the resources in the cloud It simplified the way that we produced things and just chatted between resources We then wanted to implement infrastructure as code and GitOps which have been covered in a few chats today Everything's declarative Everything's in version control All the benefits that you get from using these methodologies we wanted to kind of use that basically And finally automated upgrades For people that had to be on call and do PKS upgrades it was a bit of a nightmare Now we just schedule it It happens at the end of the month whenever we need So these were our kind of targeted improvements things that we up front thought we could gain from this migration So we had a rough idea of what we wanted How are we actually going to build that out and create this platform There's two of us on stage It takes all sorts of minds It takes all sorts of skill sets to make this happen So I've highlighted some of them here We had experts from multiple clouds not just Azure We had former developers like myself and Andrew Networking We have a platform engineering team and a DevOps team When those terms kind of made a bit more sense but now they've all kind of merged And then there was a little bit of input from architects A very minor input from the system design side So yeah it's not just the two of us on stage that did all this When we came to building the platform we started off with the clusters themselves And Terraform was the obvious choice We were well versed in it for other tools other resources just never made the Kubernetes cluster side of it using Terraform before The way we did Terraform at the time was again running through Azure DevOps pipelines and we managed our own state our own secrets our own environments which was less than ideal So we looked at tooling that could help us with this and we went for Spacelift We don't work for Spacelift We don't have any affiliation but it's an absolutely cracking tool And it's completely changed our relationship with Terraform really It handles all the So like I say no affiliation but that really helped us accelerate in building this platform We then used Fluxed for the GitHub side of things I don't want to say too much wrong about Fluxed because the actual creator and maintainer is here somewhere So we implemented it because it just looked like it was a much more user friendly tool for our side from the system side as in not application developers which is why we didn't go for Argo at the time And we used that to configure everything all the standard tooling that we need on our clusters So you spin up a new cluster and you get the GitOps operators running on them as and then it pulls in whatever we think the cluster config should be And then finally once we were happy with what we had from the platform side of we started to engage with app dev teams At the time we thought this was the first thing we should do and we had a bit of back and forth about when should we engage with developers and who's going to use it But we decided that ultimately the developers don't know what they don't know So we thought we'll build our platform first make sure our house is in order and then we can go out to them and say this is how we engage So that's kind of how the platform was conceived from start to A little bit of a deeper dive on Flux because again KCD is more Kubernetes related This is just a little outline of the repo that we have kind of made slightly more generic but it's just a little bit of something to see that's a bit more interesting than some of these diagrams But the decisions that we made were to move to fewer larger clusters So perhaps in terms of scale this is you know peanuts to some of you in the room but we went for four non prod clusters and two in prod This is based on kind of back of the envelope calculations of the number of workloads we had and resilience and whatnot So we made them more generic as well Previously our clusters were tied to the workstream that the applications lived in so clients or investments or what have you And we realized that was kind of more you know we wanted cattle not pets that kind of idea So completely generic They are called things like cluster 1 2 3 and 4 Keep it nice and simple and And then we really made heavy use of the base and overlay flux configuration So we have that base folder You make a single update to a single file and update all your clusters in that particular environment So these decisions here were just generally how we wanted to configure flux There's all sorts of ways to do it We tried to like stick with best practice where we could but you know this is what we have at the moment And then kind of finally from me we want to embrace open source tools a lot more We've been to a few of these events KCDs KubeCons whatever And you know we've seen the kind of work people in the room do We also want to kind of push it If you're working in an enterprise it can be tempting to go for a paid product because you get an SLA and what have you But there are actually a number of excellent tools that most clusters run on So we want to really embrace that and try and kind of push for these This is just the ones that we use in the majority of our We do have other open source tools We're trying to push for more wherever we can But generally it's just a way of making sure that we're staying with the community and moving with all the best practice that that comes with And now I'll pass over to Andrew to talk about how we actually migrated people to the platform OK so we have got this fantastic new cloud native Kubernetes platform But as the old saying goes just because you build it doesn't mean they will come So what do we have to do to actually get these 1600 developer workloads onto this new platform So first step is identifying those workloads and finding out who owns it who's going to take responsibility for the application and its migration And it just opens up that dialogue with a developer with a development team as to what's going on in the next steps We then need to create a migration checklist So this is just a step by step guide of how do we actually technically do this migration It needs to be written and documented in a way so even the graduates we're taking through our team can pick it up and run with it For obvious reasons we're going to migrate non prod first sensible reason Aiming to do 100  of non prods aiming to do about 95  of prods Main reasons being that we anticipate that some of our production applications are going to need to remain on prem because they need access to on prem systems resources or databases So that's the plan And then this is all a very iterative process We're going to come across issues we're going to come across challenges and we just need to make sure that everyone working on this it's known it's documented our migration checklist is updated with that in mind So what does the actual migration checklist look like at a closer level App owner survey Like I mentioned before we need to open up this dialogue and discussion with the application owner First question that we ask is this still needed Is it still being used Can it be decommissioned If so it's just a matter of scaling that down taking that as complete and moving on to the next one If it's still needed we go through the process on the technical side creating namespaces updating firewall rules doing a code change to update like deployment pipelines and then ultimately just deploying to our new AKS cluster All going well we just scaled down our old PKS deployment If it doesn't go well it's just a case of maybe reverting that DNS change scaling up the PKS deployment and then just scaling back down the AKS one So we're not actually deleting anything at this point We've got a very safe backup plan if that's needed The actual non prod migration itself for those that like a graph and stats this is what it looks like You can see we did just under 1 300 deployments Took about maybe two and a half months a bit of a slow start and then kind of start ticking up after a For non prod migrations developers are quite happy for this to happen during in They don't mind a bit of downtime not that we're expecting any but they're a little bit more relaxed But for production for comparison you can see here about a quarter of the number of deployments just under 400 but actually took us longer Developers weren't as happy or a bit more cautious about how things happened during work hours A bit more coordination was needed just to maybe find a time that suited them It was much more us working around their work lines and timelines as opposed to us just migrating it for them So that gives you an idea of what that kind of looked like Adding both timelines together it took the best part of a year You can see a kind of glaring flatline around Christmas when we all took a break Then we came back to it in January and just finished off the last of it So the good news with this is that we actually migrated 100  of our applications the ones that we anticipate that need to be left on prem There were some issues but they were resolved from an engineering point of view so they're quite happy for them to be moved So as far as we go we're quite happy with this but just a massive effort in place As we built these new Kubernetes platforms we also underwent an internal training program called KubeCamp So this was a blended learning where we had access to a cloud guru We're also doing internal homemade labs We also had SMEs present Bailey Gifford specific context around how we use Kubernetes So this was really to allow developers to be more confident in debugging and fixing their own issues You can see here a 50  reduction in Kubernetes related support tickets which is a massive win and 100  self reported skill increase So again it's just allowing developers who maybe haven't been exposed to just give them the chance to learn about it give them the Bailey Gifford context and just give them confidence to debug things on their own time So this was a massive internal success And we're on to just finished our ninth iteration over 100 attendees But externally we were also nominated for the Best Use of Blended Learning from the Learning Technologies Award So a massive success all around And again the main outcome is just giving the developers more confidence to debug and do what they need to do And again this wasn't an end goal but we did encourage developers to go and get certified And we're very proactive in our self development and learning within Bailey Gifford so it's always encouraged And you can see the CCAD exam here has been a massive success Also happy to say that we have two KubeSternauts within Bailey Gifford I think the first two of 25 in And over the last couple of weeks Duncan also got his Golden KubeSternaut Award So first in Scotland So congratulations Duncan Yeah yeah That's a good opportunity for a water break Cheers That was unexpected He's still waiting for his golden cap so if anyone knows him he's going to get it But yeah so that's it So we did our migrations but that's not the end Like what did we learn What are the lessons learned as part of this So if you remember this slide from the start these were our main pain points This is where we were at So what does this look like now So we've got our terraformed AKS clusters We're no longer using bash scripts We're no longer using Azure DevOps We've got fluxed platform workloads So again removing those bash scripts removing those pipelines Everything's in state Everything's in our code base Everything goes through that PR change We've got a more robust CICD as part of that And code is now the source of truth And that's a really big thing here It's like everything can be tied back to a code base Everything can be seen in state So I believe we achieved what we wanted to But we also saw some extra benefits while going alongside this And these were things that either just popped up along or just unseen happenstances As I mentioned before we've got 100  of our production workloads migrated So we're now on a single cloud platform We're able to just completely decommission and remove our old on prem clusters So massive win from a maintenance point of view for us as platform owners Massive win from a cost point of view Massive win So it was great Workload decommissions like I said we managed to decommission I think it was like 15  of our application So again now that we're in the cloud if we're not using something we need to get into that mindset of just getting it removed and decommissioned or switched off or whatever So good from that point of view Also good from a housekeeping point of view An Azure managed identity So now that we're in the cloud now we're in Azure we can assign an Azure managed identity to a Kubernetes service account From a developer's point of view they can get rid of access keys and secrets It just allows that resource to resource communication without any of that authentication path that we were getting before So a big win for But for us as platform owners as cloud engineers we're very happy with it as well Very much something that we're using on a day to day basis now Flux upgrades So again big fans of But this wasn't the part of this that was unforeseen It's like the day two operations If we ever want to upgrade like a helm chart of an open source tool that we're it's a code change and a pull request and then Flux handles the rest It's just nice to have day two It's been very nice Our workflow has changed around it And then cluster scaling So now that we're in the cloud everything's terraformed We can just scale up and scale down as and when we need to We don't have to worry about pre provisioning things We don't have to worry about things just sitting there anymore It should all just kind of be handled for us in a much quicker and streamlined way So all in all a great success We pat ourselves on the back I don't know if I've been very positive about this the whole time There has been some not so nice lessons learned as part of this Migration fatigue is a big one As I said before this was the best part of a year A massive amount of engineering resource A massive amount of developer communication and We pushed ourselves to get the last of the migrations done before the end of the year the start of this year But I'd be doing any justice if we didn't talk about this because it was a massive project a massive effort across the board So it has to be This thing doesn't just happen overnight It took a lot of planning took a lot of effort from a lot of people and a lot of Code divisibility So it's not often maybe we don't do it enough get to peek at the code bases for our application developers and see what's going on And we do have a golden path to allow developers to follow a certain structured CICD template in a standardized way But what we were seeing is that actually developers at the time they wouldn't always follow this or maybe they'd work around issues or maybe they'd just go off and do their own thing So again it's just now that we've opened this dialogue with maybe we need to keep it open and chat about it and see like why are they working around these things If what we've provided for them isn't suitable why is that And again this ties into customer focus It's just differing views what the developers have as their priority and adding business value and what we have as our priority as platform owners and maintainers And it kind of ties into this mindset shift as well So you're in the cloud you're paying for what you use and you're also paying for what you don't use So turn things off scale things down delete things where necessary And that's it I think a big part of this is the communication and it's been said a lot this morning already is keeping that dialogue open with our Get the buy in take people with you on the journey and it's a community effort not just internally within Be the Gifford but the communities the conferences like this the open source community the cloud native community It's just I mean I'd be lying if I said that we didn't build a new platform on the shoulders of because a lot of these tools are open source We're seeing like Stefan's talk this morning again We're using a lot of tools that have had a massive amount of community effort involved and then we're just bringing it in and building our own platforms on top of it So again just acknowledging that fact Okay so built our platform migrated everything we've learned some lessons what's next Looking at the So again looking at open source tools again we're talking about self service platforms enabling user autonomy control So now that we're terraforming a lot of our system workloads namespaces whatever how do we allow developers just to be self served and do that by themselves Service mesh service to service communication Again just looking towards industry looking at what's going on and looking at other tools that are coming up We've already brought this in we've already started looking at it Policy as code So again big fans of using Codebase as your source of We're using tools like WIS as our cloud security platform but how do we then start writing policy as code instead of just like policy as manual intervention And we're starting to look at tools like Kubernetes to handle this for us as well So it's just another natural step towards using Codebase to handle things for you And now that we're in the cloud and using cloud native applications I think it's time that we revisit our observability framework and look at the tools that we are using and what we think we can utilize better What are the new pain points And again just to tie into this open source tool an ongoing review of Duncan mentioned Spacelift again before We don't use open source tools because they're free at a cost to us We use the right tool for the right job whether that's open source whether it's a third party vendor It's just an ongoing evaluation of what we're actually using what we need what are the new pain points what we think we can do better And I think that's really just about time to wrap it up So just to revisit where we were Our self managed clusters on prem We talked about the pain points We talked about what we wanted and what we think we could achieve and do better We built this new cloud native Kubernetes single platform We migrated 100  of our applications which has been a massive win but it came at the cost of migration fatigue a lot of engineering resource a lot of effort from a lot of people And that kind of ties into the DevOps VPs of people process and products I think we've learned that we need to keep that kind of dialogue open with our developers and just keep it open not just opening it as and when we need it A lot of talk this morning about creating a and owning it as a product and just involving people as part of it So with that in mind the migration has come to an end So as this talk I thank you all very much for listening and stopping by I'm not sure we have time for questions or are we taking questions So apparently we've got time for So if you have any we'll take them First of all thank you so much Chandra and Duncan
